I learned a ton about writing, with a focus on writing about medical/public health/scientific topics but also a lot about writing in general. We worked on a bunch of different styles of writing: hard news story, personal narrative, fiction, and patient profile, with the greatest focus on New-Yorker style feature pieces. I learned about how to frame scientific/medical information for the public, and about journalists' responsibilities to the public.

I developed so many skills while taking this class. First of all, I better honed my ability to read medical writing for craft, and correspondingly I improved my ability to write and assess my own writing for craft, and not simply content. I learned about the power and meaning of each word in a piece of writing, and it was both fun and challenging learning about more of a journalistic approach to writing; in my courses, I feel like I have mostly focused on expository and scientific writing.

A major strength is how often students are writing. I also loved how open ended the final paper topic was because it allowed me to research a topic I have always been interested in, but never had the time to learn about. Something slightly frustrating was that our writing always had to be written at a level where the general public could understand. The general public apparently has no understanding of basic science, so I spent a lot of time diluting down my work.

Weakness: no regular office hours, although Professor was always willing to meet; having a set time a week would be nice to drop in 

Strength: multiple meetings per week, critical analyses of readings

I would absolutely recommend English 121: Writing about Medicine and Public Health to any other student. I did not expect to like it at all because it was a writing credit, but it ended up being my favorite class of the semester. Really, just take it if you have the chance. Read on for an excessive amount of details: We read some amazing pieces of writing about medicine/public health/science, analyzed their strategies and style, and applied those findings to our own writing. We did a wide variety of assignments: a news story, a segment of a play, a personal narrative, some short explanatory writing, two patient profiles, and the final paper-- a New-Yorker style piece about a topic of our choosing. I learned a lot of writing strategies (how to not freeze when staring at a blank page) and a ton about style. It was a lot more journalism-focused than I had imagined, which meant that I ended up learning a lot about research and how to interview people in addition to learning about writing. Most of the assignments were short (1 paragraph to 3 pages), other than the 8-10 page final paper. There was a fair amount of reading (mostly short pieces) and we usually had just a few days for each draft, which forced me to work on writing quickly-- which was super useful for my growth as a writer. In addition, Professor Epstein is brilliant. She is very knowledgeable about both medicine/public health/science and writing/journalism, so I really trusted her, and she gave very useful, detailed feedback on my writing. She offered a ton of support during the writing process, and I also had fun talking with her about various topics after class. Plus, our class of about a dozen students grew pretty close over the term and we were able to have interesting discussions and share helpful feedback during workshopping sessions.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student strongly interested in health and medicine and how to best communicate it to different audiences. In the future, if I ever want to write news articles or New Yorker-style articles about relevant health topics, I feel that this class really prepared me to do so.
